In Julia, Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".

In Julia, you can define a function to clean column names as follows:

```julia
function clean_column(col::String)
    return lowercase(replace(col, r"^[ \t\r\n]+|[ \t\r\n]+$" => "")) # Strip leading and trailing whitespace
        .replace(r"[\s-]+" => "_") # Replace spaces and hyphens with underscores
end
```

This function does the following:

1. Lowercases the column name using `lowercase()`.
2. Strips any leading or trailing whitespace using a regular expression that matches one or more occurrences of space, tab, carriage return, or newline characters at the beginning (`^`) or end (`$`) of the string.
3. Replaces sequences of spaces and hyphens with underscores using another regular expression that matches one or more occurrences of either whitespace or hyphen characters.

Here's how you can use this function:

```julia
julia> clean_column("My Column")
"my_column"

julia> clean_column("  MyColumn-  ")
"mycolumn"
```

Please note that the `replace` function in Julia 1.6 and later versions allows for a more concise syntax with its `=>` operator, which was not available before. If you are using an older version of Julia, you would need to use the `sub` function or write a custom function to achieve the same result.
